title: Question about Chapter 7 Automatic Stay?
question: I am in Chapter 7. I listed a particular creditor on my schedules, and they were also on the mail matrix. This creditor also contacted me at least 30 unique times since I filed my chapter 7 petition to harass, enforce, and collect this debt (by email). I had also emailed a copy of my petition notice to the lawyer representing this creditor the day I filed my petition. Before my chapter 7 petition date, I applied to set aside this default judgment of this creditor. The hearing date came, and this creditor attended the hearing and did not inform the state court that I was in chapter 7 and moved forward with the hearing. Should this creditor have asked the bankruptcy court to lift the stay to reply to my application and attend the hearing? I thought the bankruptcy stay applies to any effort, attempts to collect a debt from a debtor? I have all of the emails and letters that were sent to me. I also have three separate call attempts from the creditor's process server (I did a reverse lookup, and the number belongs to the process server - I created a PDF of this proof).
answers: If you have not already done so, file a Notice of Automatic Stay with the state court. File it as a pleading in your particular case pending before the state court.

You and your attorney should be contacting the US Trustee immediately, demanding that s/he take action immediately to protect the estate.
Your attorney can also calendar a motion for sanctions for violation of the stay.
GOOD LUCK

I agree with much that has been said before me.

In general bankruptcy debtors' are entitled to an automatic stay, and a creditor who has been properly notified of the Bankruptcy filing should cease attempts to collect on the debt, including moving forward with a collection lawsuit, and sending collection correspondence. Sometimes a bankruptcy debtor is only entitled to a limited automatic stay, or no stay at all. If you filed a prior bankruptcy case with in 1 year prior the instant case, the stay is 30 days, if not extended. If (for some reason) you filed 2x cases with the year before the current case, there is no stay, unless imposed. Lastly, there is the possibility that relief from stay was obtained, but I am hearing/seeing anything in your question that would cause me to believe this is the sort of debt, where a relief from stay motion would be filed.

Call your attorney, or consult with an attorney. GOOD LUCK!

If everything you state is true, then the creditor violated the automatic stay. That being said, did you inform the state court of the filing of the bk? If you had, then the state court would have never conducted the hearing. It was up to you to inform the state court that your filed a bk, and to vacate a hearing that you requested, or a minimum, show up at your own hearing. A bankruptcy judge may very well find a violation technical violation of the stay. You may want to hire an attorney to assist you. Good Luck.

You may have a claim for violation of the automatic stay assuming that you did not previously file a bankruptcy which was dismissed in the previous year before this petition. You will probably need an attorney to file a petition in bankruptcy court seeking sanctions.

Your rights are being trampled upon. The automatic stay is called that for one simple reason: it's automatic. While there are limited exceptions to the automatic stay, none would have application to the creditor who has been violating your rights.

You have described those violations in an articulate manner and it would appear that you have done a good job of documenting the violations and also have gone beyond the required notification procedures to make this creditor aware of the pendency of the bankruptcy. At this juncture, you should be seeking to enforce the automatic stay by initiating contempt proceedings against this creditor and its counsel.

If you have an attorney handling the bankruptcy, make certain your attorney is aware of the situation. He or she can take the appropriate steps. If you are not represented by counsel, you should consult with any one of the many qualified bankruptcy specialists who are listed in Avvo or can be identified through the State Bar website where attorneys can be found based upon their certified specialties. https://members.calbar.ca.gov/search/ls_search.aspx.

In addition to being held in contempt for violation of the automatic stay, the court can award you attorney fees as well as damages for violation of the automatic stay, including punitive damages were appropriate.

That's interesting; YES, the stay applies to any further action in state court except to stay or dismiss the case. So technically you could have something there; the creditor arguing against vacating the default could be in some trouble.

The easier part is that the creditor obviously violated the stay in other respects.
